Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Significance of Intercultural Social Networks in Emergent Commercial Markets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Economic anthropologists and sociologists have long established that commercial relationships are "embedded" in social and cultural processes. As various economies become increasingly globalized, there are new challenges for scientific understandings of how economic relationships can be established and thrive in contexts where entrepreneurs are informed by different cultural, social, and political expectations. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, scientifically grounded fieldwork, explores the practices and processes that do and do not lead to greater trust and mutually satisfying outcomes between individuals of varying national origins in emergent commercial markets.

Derek Sheridan, under the supervision of Dr. Catherine Lutz of Brown University, proposes to ask how everyday economic and social interactions between merchants and entrepreneurs of diverse national backgrounds shape both the understanding of international relations, and the implications these relations have for viable commercial networks in emergent markets. To answer these questions, the researcher will spend a year focused on Chinese migrants in Tanzania. Given the growing economic presence of Chinese entrepreneurs in Africa, and the enormous importance of Africa's resources and economic growth to China's ascendency, this is an ideal context for studying how the emergence of important commercial relationships in the twenty-first century. The researcher will follow how Chinese-Tanzanian relationships develop and evolve in different contexts and under different conditions. Through fieldwork, he will trace how people evaluate each other, develop trust and/or mistrust in each other, and develop the everyday ethics and "rules of the game" that allow them to conduct business with each other. Through a combination of extended observation and interviews, the researcher will follow how people make sense of their experiences through stories, and how they share these experiences with others; and in the process contribute to popular knowledge in both China and Tanzania about Sino-African relationships. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, the project would generate data significant commercial relationships between African and China, the understanding of which is critical to economic competitiveness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Derek Sheridan has completed research for his dissertation “The Significance of Intercultural Social Networks in Emergent Commercial Markets” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During his funding period, he spent twelve months in Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania studying everyday experiences and interpersonal relations between Chinese migrant entrepreneurs and their Tanzanian associates. The growing presence of Chinese investors and workers in Tanzania, like in Africa more generally, has attracted wide attention globally. However, the understanding of this recent phenomena has been challenged by a lack of on-the-ground research, leading to the circulation of myths and rumors about either the scale or nature of the Chinese presence. Most research on the topic has directed attention to the relationship between the Chinese state and its policies, and individual African governments. This project looks instead at the diversity of Chinese actors in Tanzania and their varied relationships with local society, and each other.

As an anthropologist, the researcher conducted participant observation, spending extensive time with Chinese migrant entrepreneurs and the Tanzanians with whom they worked. He both observed their daily lives and listened to them describe their experiences and views of life in Tanzania. He conducted research with Chinese wholesale trading shops, a Chinese supermarket, and with Chinese investors exploring opportunities in manufacturing and/or minerals. He also participated in cultural projects including Chinese New Year performances held in Tanzania, the production of documentaries by visiting Chinese students, the restoration of a Chinese graveyard by the employee of a Chinese firm, and a Tanzanian martial arts school. These research sites allowed him to gather on-the-ground data from a number of sites where there are significant relationships between Chinese expatriates and Tanzanians, and to do so over an extended period of time.

The research makes an important contribution to the study of China-Africa relations by exploring how ordinary Chinese and ordinary Tanzanians make sense of the China-Africa relationship on the basis of their individual experiences. These are perspectives both different from the official statements from governments, but also more in-depth and contextualized than an opinion survey. The research demonstrates that interpersonal relationships between Chinese and Tanzanians are closely affected by ideas both Chinese and Tanzanians have about how their societies compare to each other in an unequal world. Chinese expatriates debate among themselves how to maintain good relationships in Tanzania and to be successful. In those areas where there are tensions, in particular, experiences of petty corruption with Tanzanian officials, there is a debate as to whether locals or Chinese are more responsible. The responses are varied. Tanzanians themselves share many of the same critiques of Tanzanian society as the Chinese do, but they may focus on different culprits.The Chinese-Tanzanian relationship is officially represented as “friendship,” and although friendships do occur between Chinese expatriates and their Tanzanian hosts, the concept of friendship itself is difficult to pursue when the two partners come from different economic backgrounds, a difference compounded by linguistic and cultural differences. Nonetheless, these tensions do create productive spaces of debate.
